elements.title: Smart Defaults for Every Host Decision Point
elements.problem: The platform presents blank fields and open choices at critical decision points (pricing, listing details, proposal response). Kris explicitly asks 'How much do you think I should rent this place for?' — he wants a default, not a decision. Thaler and Sunstein demonstrate that defaults shape 25%+ of outcomes. When the platform fails to provide defaults, hosts either abandon (depleted decision-makers default to denial) or accept random/poor outcomes. The current listing wizard starts blank; the pricing field starts blank; the proposal response requires active engagement. Every blank field is a choice architecture failure.
elements.solution: Pre-fill every decision point with an intelligent default that produces a good outcome if accepted without modification. (1) Pricing: Pre-fill with a recommended nightly rate based on location comps, property type, and schedule. Show the default prominently with a 'Recommended' label and allow adjustment via slider, not blank input. (2) Listing details: Pre-populate from agent call notes and property address data (neighborhood description, nearby transit, building type). (3) Proposal response: Default to 'Accept' for proposals within the host's stated parameters, with a 'Review details' option rather than requiring active acceptance. (4) Lease renewal: Default to auto-renewal with the same guest, requiring opt-out rather than opt-in. Each default must be the choice a well-informed, attentive host would make.

evidence.quote: How much do you think I should rent this place for? Cause I pay about $5,500 a month.
evidence.insight: Kris provides his cost anchor ($5,500/mo) and explicitly asks for a recommendation. He is not a price-setter; he is a default-accepter. The platform must serve this behavior, not fight it.

evidence.quote: You can often increase participation rates by 25 percent, and sometimes by a lot more than that, simply by shifting from an opt-in to an opt-out design. Setting default options can have huge effects on outcomes.
evidence.insight: The research is unambiguous: defaults are the most powerful single choice architecture tool. Every blank field on the platform is a missed opportunity to apply this tool.

evidence.quote: If I have someone who's someone regular, cause obviously they'll get a discount because I'd prefer to work with one or two.
evidence.insight: Kris wants a default guest arrangement — not a marketplace of options. The platform should support 'preferred guest' as a status quo, not force re-evaluation each cycle.

evidence.quote: People have a general tendency to stick with their current situation. A study conducted in the late 1980s looked at decisions of participants in a pension plan. The median number of changes in the asset allocation over a lifetime was zero.
evidence.insight: Once a default is set, hosts will rarely change it. This makes the quality of the initial default critical — it must be right the first time.

elements.user_goal: Get a working, well-priced listing without having to research the market, learn the platform, or make decisions I'm not qualified to make.
elements.company_goal: Increase listing completion rate and pricing accuracy by providing intelligent defaults that produce good outcomes even when hosts accept without deliberation.
elements.time_budget: Each decision point should require under 5 seconds for a host who accepts the default. Modification should add no more than 30 seconds per field.
anti_goals: DO NOT present blank fields at any critical decision point. A blank field is a failed default.

DO NOT label defaults as 'suggested' or 'recommended' in a way that implies the host should override them. The default should feel like 'the right answer' unless the host has specific knowledge to the contrary.
DO NOT use defaults as a way to manipulate hosts into pricing below market. Defaults must optimize for the host's outcome, not the platform's booking volume.
DO NOT remove the ability to override defaults. Libertarian paternalism requires that all options remain available.
elements.success_metric: Default acceptance rate: percentage of hosts who accept the pre-filled default at each decision point without modification. Target: above 60% for pricing, above 80% for listing details, above 50% for proposal acceptance.

elements.title: Delegated Host Access: Multi-User Account Architecture
elements.problem: Kris's listing is under Christiana's account. Kris cannot see his own listing photos. Bryant needs to upload photos on their behalf. This three-person collaboration (property owner + account manager + agent) is forced through a single-user account model. The platform's choice architecture assumes the host IS the account holder, but for premium delegator-hosts like Kris, the account holder is a proxy. This creates a fragile dependency — if Christiana is unavailable, the listing stalls. The Nudge book warns that 'seemingly arbitrary decisions will have subtle influences on how the people who use the building interact.' The single-user account model is one such arbitrary decision with major downstream consequences.
elements.solution: Implement a multi-role access model for listings. (1) Owner role: The property owner (Kris) can view the listing, receive proposals, approve guests, and see earnings — even if they did not create the account. Access via a simple invite link, no separate account creation required. (2) Manager role: The account holder (Christiana) can edit listings, manage photos, handle logistics. (3) Agent role: The assigned agent (Bryant) can edit photos, adjust pricing, and manage proposals on behalf of the host — with visibility but not ownership. (4) Each role receives appropriate notifications. The owner gets decision-requiring items (proposals, reviews). The manager gets operational items (photo requests, schedule changes). The agent gets system items (listing performance, pricing recommendations).

evidence.quote: Christiana has a split lease account and the listing is under her account currently... She's having a problem. Like...
evidence.insight: The three-person collaboration breaks down because the platform has no concept of delegated access. The account holder can't log in, the property owner can't see the listing, and the agent must manually bridge the gap.

evidence.quote: There are many parallels between choice architecture and more traditional forms of architecture. A crucial parallel is that there is no such thing as a neutral design. Seemingly arbitrary decisions, such as where to locate the bathrooms, will have subtle influences.
evidence.insight: The single-user account model is an 'arbitrary' architectural decision that profoundly shapes who can participate in the host journey. It's not neutral — it excludes delegator-hosts.

evidence.quote: If what you can do, if you just send them over to me, I'd be happy to put them on your listing for you.
evidence.insight: Bryant informally creates an agent role — acting as photo uploader on behalf of the host. The platform should formalize this workflow instead of requiring ad hoc workarounds.

elements.user_goal: Have my listing managed well even though I don't use the platform directly. See what matters to me (proposals, earnings, guest quality) without managing what doesn't matter to me (photos, descriptions, logistics).
elements.company_goal: Capture high-value delegator-hosts who own premium properties but will not personally manage a platform account. These hosts have the most valuable listings but the lowest direct engagement.
elements.time_budget: Owner role setup should take under 60 seconds (click invite link, verify identity). Manager-to-owner handoffs (e.g., 'approve this proposal') should take under 15 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT require the property owner to create a full account to participate. The default for premium delegators is that someone else handles the account.
DO NOT send all notifications to the account holder. Route decision-requiring notifications to the property owner.
DO NOT allow the single-user model to be the only option. Some hosts will always delegate.
DO NOT make the agent role invisible. Agents like Bryant are already performing this role informally — formalize and empower it.
elements.success_metric: Multi-user listing adoption: percentage of listings with more than one person contributing. Target: 20% of new listings use delegated access within 6 months. Secondary: reduction in agent manual interventions (photo uploads, pricing changes made on behalf of hosts).

elements.title: Loss Aversion Addressing: Asset Protection Visibility
elements.problem: Kris's most visceral concern is asset protection ('I've got some really good art in that apartment'). Loss aversion means this concern carries twice the emotional weight of income potential. Bryant addresses it verbally (credit checks, vetting, payment guarantee), but the platform surfaces income potential (pricing, earnings) far more prominently than loss protection (vetting process, insurance, guest quality assurance). The current choice architecture is income-framed when it should be loss-protection-framed for premium hosts.
elements.solution: Rebalance the platform's information architecture to give loss protection equal or greater prominence than income potential. (1) During evaluation: Lead with 'How we protect your property' before 'How much you can earn.' The vetting process, credit checks, and payment guarantee should be above-the-fold content, not buried in FAQ. (2) During active lease: Surface guest quality signals prominently — verified status, reviews from other hosts, credit check completion. Show a 'Property Protection' status indicator on the lease dashboard. (3) During onboarding: Allow hosts to flag high-value assets (art, electronics, furniture) and receive a custom protection recommendation. (4) Frame the payment guarantee as loss prevention, not income assurance: 'Your $5,500/month rent is guaranteed — you will never miss a payment because of a guest.'

evidence.quote: I've got some really good art in that apartment. So I want to make sure that the, you know, how do you vet people?... Our guests are really a cut above the rest. We are very selective.
evidence.insight: Kris's art concern is unprompted and emotional. It's the only moment in the call where he asks 'how' rather than accepting a recommendation. This signals high anxiety that the platform must address proactively.

evidence.quote: People hate losses. Roughly speaking, the prospect of losing something makes you twice as miserable as the prospect of gaining the same thing makes you happy... those with mugs demand roughly twice as much to give them up as others are willing to pay to get one.
evidence.insight: The 2:1 loss aversion ratio means that for every $1 of income potential shown, the platform needs $2 worth of protection assurance to maintain emotional equilibrium for premium hosts.

elements.user_goal: Know with certainty that my property and belongings are protected before, during, and after each guest stay. Feel that Split Lease takes my concerns about my space as seriously as I do.
elements.company_goal: Retain premium hosts (high-value properties) who are loss-averse and will churn if they perceive insufficient protection. These hosts have the most valuable listings and highest retention potential.
elements.time_budget: Protection assurance should be visible within 2 seconds of any screen load during active lease. The vetting summary for each guest should be scannable in under 5 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT lead with income/earnings for premium hosts. Lead with protection and make income secondary.
DO NOT use generic 'We vet all guests' language. Specifics matter: 'Credit check complete. Landlord references verified. Payment pre-authorized.'
DO NOT hide the vetting process behind a 'Learn More' link. It should be default-visible, not opt-in.
DO NOT treat all hosts the same. Kris's $5,500/mo premium property needs different loss-aversion messaging than a $800/mo room.
elements.success_metric: Host anxiety reduction: measured by support ticket volume related to guest quality/vetting concerns. Target: 30% reduction after implementing visible protection signals. Secondary: premium host retention rate above 85%.

elements.title: Agent-as-Choice-Architect: Formalize the Human Nudge Pipeline
elements.problem: Bryant performs the role of choice architect throughout the call — framing options, setting anchors, providing defaults, managing multi-party logistics. But this work is invisible to the platform. There is no mechanism for the agent to encode their choice architecture work (price recommendations, listing improvements, host preferences) into the platform in a way that persists and compounds. Each call is a one-time human performance that the platform does not capture or learn from.
elements.solution: Create an agent-facing workflow that allows agents to encode choice architecture decisions into the platform after each call. (1) Post-call agent dashboard: After a host call, the agent fills in a structured form: recommended price (becomes the default), host preferences (guest type, schedule), host concerns (asset protection level), and listing improvements needed (photos, description). (2) These inputs become the smart defaults that populate the host's experience. When Kris logs in (or Christiana logs in), they see Bryant's recommendations as pre-filled defaults. (3) Track which agent recommendations are accepted vs modified — this data improves future defaults. (4) The agent's name and photo appear next to their recommendations, transferring human trust to digital defaults.

evidence.quote: We kind of have a tool basically based on similar listings and we use location as well. We can kind of get a price estimate.
evidence.insight: Bryant describes a pricing tool that produces a recommendation. But this recommendation exists only in the phone conversation — it never becomes a platform default. The agent's work is lost.

evidence.quote: Choice architects can make major improvements to the lives of others by designing user-friendly environments. Many of the most successful companies have succeeded in the marketplace for exactly that reason.
evidence.insight: Bryant IS the choice architect. The platform should amplify his impact by persisting his choices, not forcing him to redo them manually each time.

evidence.quote: If what you can do, if you just send them over to me, I'd be happy to put them on your listing for you.
evidence.insight: Bryant informally extends his choice architect role to listing content (photo management). The platform should provide a formal agent editing interface, not rely on email-forwarded photos.

elements.user_goal: See the platform reflect what my agent already knows about me and my property, so I don't have to repeat myself or make decisions the agent already made for me.
elements.company_goal: Scale the high-conversion impact of agent calls by encoding call-derived insights as platform defaults. Each call should improve the platform experience for all future interactions, not be a one-time event.
elements.time_budget: Agent post-call encoding should take under 3 minutes. Host should see agent-derived defaults immediately upon next login.
anti_goals: DO NOT make agent work invisible to the host. If Bryant set the price recommendation, Kris should see 'Bryant recommended $X/night based on similar listings.'
DO NOT require agents to use a separate tool to encode insights. It should be part of the existing CRM/dashboard flow.
DO NOT treat agent recommendations as lower quality than host self-service inputs. For delegator-hosts, agent-curated defaults ARE the best defaults.
DO NOT create a dependency on agents — smart defaults should also work from algorithmic recommendations when no agent input is available.
elements.success_metric: Agent-encoded default adoption rate: percentage of hosts who accept agent-set defaults without modification. Target: above 70%. Secondary: time-to-first-listing for hosts with agent calls vs without.

elements.title: Recurring Guest as Default: Status Quo Bias for Retention
elements.problem: Kris explicitly wants 'one or two' regular guests rather than a revolving marketplace. But the platform treats each lease cycle as independent — requiring new proposals, new vetting, new decisions. This fights the host's natural status quo bias. The Nudge book shows that the median number of changes to pension allocations over a lifetime is zero — people don't change defaults. If Split Lease makes 'same guest, same terms' the default, hosts like Kris will retain for years. If the platform makes each cycle feel like a new decision, it forces the host out of their preferred status quo.
elements.solution: Design the retention flow around status quo bias. (1) At lease end, default to renewal with the same guest at the same terms. Frame it as: 'Your lease with [Guest Name] renews on [date]. Same terms. No action needed.' The host must actively opt out to change guests. (2) When a guest's lease is ending and they want to return, auto-generate a renewal proposal that the host receives as a confirmation, not a decision. (3) Create a 'Preferred Guest' status that gives specific guests auto-renewal privileges. (4) For returning guests, skip the vetting display (already vetted) and show a tenure signal: 'Guest since [date] — 3 successful stays.'

evidence.quote: If I have someone who's someone regular, cause obviously they'll get a discount because I'd prefer to work with one or two.
evidence.insight: Kris is asking for a status quo arrangement. He wants to find one or two guests and then stop making decisions. The platform must support this 'set and forget' model.

evidence.quote: The median number of changes in the asset allocation over a lifetime was, believe it or not, zero. In other words, over the course of their careers, more than half of the participants made exactly no changes.
evidence.insight: If pension participants never change their allocation, Kris will never change his guest — if the platform makes the current guest the default. This is the strongest retention mechanism available.

elements.user_goal: Find one or two great guests and work with them repeatedly without having to re-evaluate, re-negotiate, or re-decide each cycle.
elements.company_goal: Maximize host retention and lease continuity by leveraging status quo bias. Recurring guest relationships are the lowest-cost, highest-LTV arrangement for the platform.
elements.time_budget: Lease renewal should require zero host action if the guest and host both want to continue. Active opt-out should take under 30 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT treat each lease cycle as a fresh marketplace event. Returning guests should be framed as continuing relationships, not new transactions.
DO NOT require active acceptance for renewals with preferred guests. The default should be continuation.
DO NOT hide the 'Preferred Guest' concept behind complex settings. It should be a single toggle or a one-tap action after the first successful stay.
DO NOT show marketplace options to hosts who have a preferred guest arrangement, unless the host actively seeks alternatives.
elements.success_metric: Guest return rate: percentage of completed leases that result in the same guest rebooking. Target: above 40% within 12 months. Secondary: host-initiated lease terminations as a percentage of all lease endings — target below 15%.
